awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research:  Genetic and ecological drivers of microbial adaptation to high-nickel serpentine soils
awd_abstract_narration:
As Earth's geology varies across the landscape, so do the properties of soil microbial communities. Variation among these microbial communities reflect an adaptive process in which genes providing benefits in a particular soil habitat are more common in the microbes dwelling there. Grassland landscapes in California are naturally punctuated by unusual patches of toxic, nickel-rich soil. For thousands of years, these patches have been sites of microbial adaptation to toxic metals. The primary goal of this project is to discover genes that allow the nitrogen fixing soil bacteria, Mesorhizobium, to tolerate toxic metals, to understand how these genes are distributed among bacteria across a patchy landscape, and to test whether these tolerance genes impose disadvantages when toxic metals are not present. Insights from this study will assist in developing strategies for biologically based remediation of human-contaminated soils and provide insight into adaptation of microbes to toxic environments. Since rhizobial bacteria, which include the Mesorhizobium, are responsible for approximately half of the biological nitrogen fixation, this research has agricultural implications. The project will integrate an undergraduate-focused training program that provides students with authentic research experiences. In this program, students will isolate bacterial strains with extremely high tolerance to toxic metals, and investigate whether their genomes include genes known to provide heavy metal tolerance. The funded work therefore contributes to understanding how organisms adapt to extreme environments and employs the efforts of young scientists at a critical stage of their training.

This project explores a critical frontier in microbial evolutionary ecology: microbial local adaptation in nature, and the role of fitness trade-offs in determining genotype distributions across heterogeneous environments. In this project, mesorhizobia, nitrogen-fixing bacteria that are easily isolated from symbiotic host plants, will be isolated from serpentine and non-serpentine soils. These Mesorhizobium strains will be subjected to straightforward laboratory physiology and fitness assays under varying nickel levels. Whole genome sequencing, transcriptional profiling, as well as molecular genetic manipulations, will also be used to characterize these strains. This highly tractable system will enable the identification of genes and mechanisms of nickel adaptation, along with direct measurement of fitness trade-offs. The project will additionally link trade-offs to the distribution of specific adaptations across a landscape of serpentine patches that vary in size and level of nickel enrichment, thereby testing general evolutionary-ecological theories about the relationship between specialization and fitness trade-offs. Undergraduates will be involved in characterization of the physiology, taxonomy, genetics, and genomics of Mesorhizobia during a course based research experience. Additionally, outreach will be performed to K-12 schools to expose these students to STEM research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Adaptation, the dynamic evolutionary process that fits organisms to their environment, is a relentless engine that generates biological diversity across variable environments. The bulk of biological diversity consists of microbial life. Yet, the genes and evolutionary processes that enable wild microbes to adapt to variable conditions across natural landscapes remain largely unknown. Plant adaptation to extreme soil conditions provides seminal examples of evolution in response to natural selection via allelic substitution. Here alleles, different versions of one gene, are inherited within a population. Beneficial alleles can then accumulate due to natural selection. However, the microbial symbionts living within plant tissues have an additional mechanism by which they can acquire novel adaptive genes: they can incorporate novel DNA from distantly related organisms into their genomes via horizontal gene transfer. Our study aimed to identify the genetic basis for environmental adaptation in wild microbes and discern whether these adaptations arose from standing allelic variation vs horizontal gene transfer.

We used comparative genomics and genetics to elucidate the evolutionary mechanisms by which rhizobia bacteria adapt to a patchwork of physiologically stressful serpentine across natural grasslands. Serpentine soils are enriched with toxic heavy metals such as nickel. We used statistical models to identify genomic variants that tended to be common in strains adapted to nickel. We then used bacterial genetic experiments to test whether these genomic variants conferred nickel adaptation. We found that the nre operon, a set of co-expressed genes predicted to encode a pump to remove nickel from a cell, is necessary and sufficient to confer adaptation to nickel. Remarkably, across the landscape, frequencies of strains possessing nre were dramatically elevated on serpentine soils, often up to 100%, while strains from adjacent sites with non-serpentine soils rarely possessed nre. This is one of the first large-scale observations of repeated clinal variation in the frequency of an adaptive genetic variant in soil bacteria.

Our work suggests that nickel tolerance in these rhizobia evolves via frequent losses, and/or gains of the nre operon via horizontal gene transfer between divergent rhizobium clades. Most of the genome of the rhizobia shows a strikingly different evolutionary history from that of the nre operon. In addition, the nre operon was embedded in a section of DNA that appeared to be a mobile genetic element. These findings reinforce recent shifts to view horizontal gene transfer as a fundamentally important source of genetic variation for microbial adaptation in the wild. However, bacterial genetic experiments also showed that that nre alleles from more nickel tolerant strains conferred greater nickel tolerance than alleles from less nickel tolerant strains. Thus, allelic substitution could also play a role in fine-tuning rhizobium adaptation to the level of nickel present in local serpentine soil. Together, our findings suggest that the interplay between evolution via gene gain and loss and evolution via allelic substitution can drive environmental adaptation in wild soil microbiota. Both processes are important to generate microbial adaptive diversity and could be tools to improve stress-adapted microbial inocula for human use.

Rhizobia are a critical source of plant-available nitrogen in terrestrial environments. Understanding how these beneficial bacteria adapt to toxins like heavy metals can inform efforts in agriculture and bioremediation that rely upon biological nitrogen fixation for fertility. Our collaboration between a small undergraduate serving institution (Washington State University, Vancouver; 3,000 undergrads), a large undergraduate serving institution (Brigham Young University; 30,000 undergrads), and a land-grant R1 university (Washington State University, Pullman; 24,500 undergrads), allowed us to enhance the diversity of backgrounds of our trainees, and catalyzed the research potential of diverse trainees at primarily undergraduate institutions. This project contributed to the training of three postdoctoral scholars, one PhD graduate student, one Masters graduate student, and 11 undergraduate students. Project research has been widely disseminated via talks and posters by project participants. We also introduced middle school students to the University setting and used games to teach fundamental evolutionary biology concepts in collaboration with Southwest Washington MESA (Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement), which recruits students from underrepresented backgrounds to pursue STEM careers. The genome sequences, strains, and data generated for this research are publicly available or will become publicly available upon publication.
